post_title: Startups Weekly: Let's see what those Y Combinator kids have been up to this time
title: Y Combinator's AI Startups Bubble; Truth Social's Alarming Losses: Startups Weekly
post_content:
Welcome to Startups Weekly: A Rundown of the Hottest Stories in the World of Startups

It's that time again - our weekly recap of everything you need to know in the world of startups! This week, we've got the scoop on Y Combinator's latest batch of startups, a deep dive into the financials of Truth Social, and much more.

Y Combinator's AI-Fueled Batch

Y Combinator, one of the most well-known startup accelerators, recently revealed its latest batch of companies. Not surprisingly, AI was a major theme, with 86 out of 247 companies identifying as AI startups. However, with 187 companies mentioning AI in their pitches, it's starting to feel like we're reaching bubble territory. We've rounded up the 18 most interesting startups from this batch, as well as the TechCrunch staff favorites.

Truth Social: The Reality of Burning Cash

Trump's Truth Social, which recently debuted on Nasdaq as $DJT, is losing money at an alarming rate. The company reported a $58 million loss on just $4 million in revenue. Unlike typical Silicon Valley startups that "burn cash now, profit later," Truth Social's story is more of a "burn cash now, and that's it" kind of tale. The company's lifelines are fraying, with no explosive user growth, no VC sugar daddies, and the unenviable position of being publicly accountable while trying to juggle a business model that seems to repel advertisers like it's made of antimatter.

Rubrik's IPO: A Tale of Modest Growth and Eye-Watering Losses

Cybersecurity darling Rubrik, which has been guzzling venture capital like it's going out of style, has filed for an IPO. The company's history of bleeding money and modest revenue growth is a common tale in the tech world. However, Rubrik's pivot to subscription models is as groundbreaking as deciding to sell software as a service.

Accel: Rethinking India and its Unicorn Collection

Accel, the venture capital firm that's been collecting Indian unic

Accel, the venture capital firm known for its Indian unicorn collection, has shifted its focus to the region. The firm has been actively investing in early-stage startups and has already seen success with several of its portfolio companies. Analysts predict that India's technology sector will continue to grow, making it an attractive market for venture capital firms.

In the latest batch of Y Combinator startups, AI was a major theme, with 86 out of 247 companies identifying as AI startups. The sheer number of AI-focused companies has raised concerns about a potential bubble, but some standout startups are making a name for themselves. Meanwhile, Truth Social, the social media platform backed by former President Donald Trump, is losing money rapidly, with a reported $58 million loss on just $4 million in revenue. The company's financial struggles are a reminder of the risks associated with startups, even those with high-profile backing.

In other news, Rubrik, a cybersecurity firm, has filed for an IPO after a history of bleeding money and modest revenue growth. However, the company's pivot to subscription models presents a unique opportunity for growth and success. And finally, Accel has shifted its focus to India's technology sector, which has seen significant growth in recent years. The firm's investments in early-stage startups highlight the potential of the region and its unicorn collection continues to grow.

post_title: Mahbod Moghadam, who rose to fame as the co-founder of Genius, has died
title: Mahbod Moghadam: Co-founder of Genius & Everipedia Dies at 41, Advocated for Creators' Payments
post_content:
Mahbod Moghadam, a Co-founder of Genius and Everipedia, Passes Away at 41

Mahbod Moghadam, an influential figure in the startup world, passed away last month at the age of 41 due to complications from a recurring brain tumor. Moghadam was known for his work as the co-founder of Genius, Everipedia, and his recent endeavors in helping creators get paid directly for their work.

The news of Moghadam's passing became widely known over the weekend, with many tributes pouring in on social media platforms. A post on Genius, attributed to his family, confirmed the unfortunate news. Former TechCrunch writer-turned-investor Josh Constine, who interviewed Moghadam in the early days of Genius, described him as a "complex, edgy, and at times problematic guy, but also genuinely funny, brilliant, and always unique."

Moghadam had been living in Los Angeles, where he was focusing on developing new ways to help creators get compensated for their work. One of his recent projects was HellaDoge, a social media platform that aimed to pay users in dogecoin for contributing dogecoin-related content. The idea was to create a platform where users would directly benefit from their participation, unlike traditional platforms such as Facebook or Twitter that generate ad revenue.

Moghadam's interest in creators' compensation can be traced back to 2009. After graduating from Yale and Stanford Law School, he became a lawyer just as the economy was collapsing. When he was let go from his law firm, he used the severance package to co-found Rap Genius with two of his Yale friends, Ilan Zechory and Tom Lehman. Rap Genius started as a platform for users to annotate and explain hip-hop lyrics, eventually expanding its remit and rebranding as Genius.

Despite the success of Genius, Moghadam's tenure at the company was marked by controversy due to his belligerent behavior. In 2014, he resigned from Genius after posting provocative comments on a murderer's manifesto on the platform. Following his resignation, Moghadam co-founded Everipedia, a blockchain
meta_desc: -based encyclopedia, with Samuel Brock and Theodor Forselius. Everipedia aimed to create a more democratic and inclusive alternative to Wikipedia by allowing users to earn cryptocurrency for their contributions.

post_title: Elon Musk says Tesla will unveil robotaxi in August
title:
Title: Tesla's Robotaxi Unveil: A Leap in Autonomous Mobility

Introduction:
Tesla, the renowned electric vehicle manufacturer, plans to unveil its robotaxi on August 8, 2
post_content:
Title: Tesla's Robotaxi Unveiling: A Leap Towards Autonomous Future

Introduction:
Tesla, the trailblazing electric vehicle manufacturer, has announced the unveiling of its much-anticipated robotaxi on August 8, 2024. This announcement comes at a time when self-driving vehicles face speed bumps due to safety concerns. The robotaxi unveiling has sparked curiosity and excitement among industry enthusiasts and investors alike.

The Unveiling:
Elon Musk, the billionaire entrepreneur and CEO of Tesla, revealed the robotaxi unveiling via a post on X. Although details about the robotaxi remain scarce, Musk confirmed the event to take place on August 8. Following the announcement, Tesla's shares surged by more than 3% in after-market trades.

Musk's Confidence in Autonomous Vehicles:
Musk has consistently boasted of Tesla's progress in developing self-driving technology. He has claimed that Tesla vehicles equipped with Full Self-Driving (FSD) will become superhuman, making it seem peculiar that humans ever drove cars while exhausted or intoxicated. Furthermore, Musk envisions Tesla owners with FSD-enabled vehicles to utilize them as robotaxis, maximizing their utility.

Challenges in the Self-Driving Landscape:
Despite the promising future of self-driving vehicles, their rollout in the United States has been cautious and bumpy. Regulators and the general public have expressed safety concerns, leading to a tentative and rocky start. San Francisco, a testing ground for autonomous vehicles, has witnessed vandalism targeting robotaxis from Google's Waymo, while GM-owned Cruise indefinitely suspended its robotaxi service due to accidents and regulatory crackdowns.

Tesla's Autopilot Feature Under Scrutiny:
Tesla's "autopilot" feature has faced criticism, with accusations that its marketing oversells its actual capabilities. The feature has come under scrutiny, further fueling safety concerns.

A Turning Point for Tesla:
The robotaxi unveiling comes on the heels of a Reuters report claiming that Tesla had abandoned Musk'
meta_desc:
"s ambitious plan for a robotaxi without a steering wheel or pedals, adopting a more practical approach. This shift underscores Tesla's commitment to realizing an autonomous future, albeit with a less radical design. The August event will shed light on Tesla's strategy for addressing safety concerns and regulatory challenges, as well as integrating its robotaxi fleet with existing ride-hailing services and transportation infrastructure.

Meta Description:

Discover Tesla's robotaxi unveiling on August 8, signaling a pragmatic shift in autonomous driving. Learn how Tesla addresses safety concerns, regulatory hurdles, and integrates robotaxis with existing transportation. Join the autonomous future revolution.

post_title: A scalable reinforcement learning-based framework to facilitate the teleoperation of humanoid robots
title: New Scalable Reinforcement Learning Framework for Humanoid Robot Teleoperation
post_content:
Title: Teleoperating Humanoid Robots with Human2HumanOid: A Revolutionary Approach

Introduction

The prospect of controlling robots remotely, also known as teleoperation, has long been a topic of interest in the field of robotics. This technology could allow humans to perform a wide range of tasks from a distance, including dangerous and complex procedures. Moreover, teleoperation could be used to collect human motion datasets, which could significantly aid in training humanoid robots for new tasks.

Recently, researchers from Carnegie Mellon University developed Human2HumanOid (H 2 O), a novel method for the effective teleoperation of human-sized humanoid robots. This pioneering approach, introduced in a paper posted to the arXiv preprint server, could enable humanoid robots to learn specific sets of movements required for various tasks, such as playing sports, pushing carts, or moving boxes.

The H 2 O System: Bridging the Gap Between Humans and Humanoids

The H 2 O system facilitates the real-time teleoperation of full-sized humanoid robots, relying only on an RGB camera. This is in contrast to many other methods, which often require complex setups and multiple sensors. The simplicity of the H 2 O system makes it easily scalable and widely applicable.

Tairan He, a co-author of the paper, explained to Tech Xplore, "We believe that human teleoperation will be essential for scaling up the data flywheel for humanoid robots, and making teleoperation accessible and easy to do is our main objective." The study combines elements from prior research, such as physics-based animation of human motions, transferring human motions to real-world humanoids, and teleoperating humanoids, into a single framework.

H 2 O: A Reinforcement Learning-Based Framework

The H 2 O teleoperation framework is based on reinforcement learning (RL), enabling real-time whole-body teleoperation of humanoid robots using just an RGB camera. The process begins with retargeting human motions to humanoid capabilities through a novel 'sim-to-data' methodology, ensuring the motions are feasible for the humanoid's physical constraints. The refined motion dataset then trains an RL-based motion imitator in simulation,
meta_desc: Master Humanoid Control with Carnegie Mellon's H 2 O Framework: Teleoperate humanoids in real-time for safer, more efficient search & rescue missions. Try it today! (19 words)

post_title: Amazon takes on India rivals with low-cost fashion store
title: Amazon's "Bazaar": A Game-Changer in India's Fast-Fashion Market
post_content:
Title: Amazon's New "Bazaar" Store: A Fierce Competitor in India's Fast-Fashion Market

Introduction

Amazon, the world's largest e-commerce company, has recently introduced a new "special store" in India, called Bazaar. This new platform focuses on affordable and trendy fashion and lifestyle products, positioning Amazon to compete more effectively against Walmart-owned Flipkart and Reliance's Ajio, both of which have made significant strides in India's fast-fashion market.

The Launch of Bazaar

Amazon quietly rolled out the Bazaar store on its India Android app in a move to attract more customers and strengthen its presence in the rapidly growing fast-fashion segment. In February, Amazon began recruiting sellers for Bazaar, promising them benefits such as hassle-free delivery, zero referral fees, and access to a massive customer base.

Bazaar's Offerings

Bazaar offers a wide variety of products, including clothing, accessories, jewelry, handbags, shoes, traditional and western wear, and home goods such as kitchenware, towels, bed linens, and decor items. With trendy t-shirts starting at 129 Indian rupees ($1.55) and sneakers priced under $3, Bazaar aims to cater to the growing popularity of affordable fast-fashion in India.

The Significance of Fast-Fashion in India

Fast-fashion's popularity is increasingly driving purchases on many Indian shopping apps, making it a critical category for Amazon, which has traditionally struggled in this segment in India. According to brokerage firm Bernstein, India's e-commerce category mix is changing, with mobile and consumer electronics' share declining. Fashion has seen the strongest growth since FY19 and now holds the highest category share.

Competition in India's Fast-Fashion Market

Amazon's Bazaar store competes with well-established players such as Flipkart, which currently leads the category, and Reliance's Ajio, which has captured approximately 30% market share in just about a year. Ajio launched its fast-fashion platform, Ajio Street, last year, offering a wide selection of clothing
meta_desc:
Meta Description: Discover affordable fashion, accessories, and footwear at Amazon's Bazaar. Trendy styles, low prices, and hassle-free delivery. Join India's growing demand now!

Keyphrase: Affordable Fashion

In this meta description, we've highlighted the main topic of the article, affordable fashion, and included a call to action for readers to discover trendy styles and low prices at Amazon's Bazaar. The description is unique, matches the content of the page, and encourages readers to take action by joining India's growing demand for affordable and fashionable items.

post_title: What we've learned from the women behind the AI revolution
title: Title: Women Shaping the AI Revolution at TechCrunch
post_content:
Title: Unveiling Women's Contributions in the AI Landscape

The artificial intelligence (AI) revolution is in full swing, with a multitude of companies raising substantial funds, regulatory bodies raising concerns, and academic institutions fostering research. The AI boom offers a wealth of opportunities for startups to introduce novel technologies to industries ripe for innovation. However, the limelight seems to be consistently cast on male figures within the AI realm. To redress this imbalance, TechCrunch's Dominic-Madori Davis and Kyle Wiggers embarked on a mission to highlight the achievements of women in AI.

In a long-running series, Davis and Wiggers engage in conversations with women who have made significant strides in AI. Their interviewees include luminaries such as:

1. Irene Solaiman: As the head of global policy at Hugging Face, Solaiman is a key player in shaping the ethical use of AI technologies, ensuring they align with societal values and norms.
2. Sarah Kreps: A professor of government at Cornell, Kreps brings AI into the political sphere, exploring its implications for international relations, security, and public policy.
3. Heidy Khlaaf: As safety engineering director at Trail of Bits, Khlaaf focuses on ensuring the security and reliability of AI systems, making them more robust and dependable for users.

The Equity podcast, a staple of TechCrunch's content offerings, features regular programming alongside these insightful interviews. Monday mornings bring the weekly kick-off show, while Wednesday and Friday play host to startup-focused news rundowns and roundtable discussions of the week's most significant developments in the tech world.

To delve deeper into the Women in AI series, Davis and Wiggers joined the Equity podcast for an enlightening conversation about their experiences, the importance of amplifying women's voices in AI, and the critical contributions these trailblazers have made to the field.

As we continue to navigate the rapidly evolving AI landscape, it's essential to acknowledge and celebrate the diverse range of talents and perspectives that shape its progression. Join TechCrunch as we explore the world of AI through the eyes of the exceptional women leading the charge in this exciting and transformative industry. Stay tuned for more inspiring stories from the Women in AI series
meta_desc:
Meta Description:
Discover the untold stories of Women in AI! Join TechCrunch's insightful interviews with female AI leaders like Irene Solaiman, Sarah Kreps, and Heidy Khlaaf. Listen to the Equity podcast for more.

post_title: Meta explains why the NYC/NJ earthquake didn't trend earlier in the day
title: Meta's Instagram Threads Falls Short During NYC-NJ Earthquake Coverage
post_content:
Instagram's Threads: A Work in Progress

Instagram Threads, Meta's answer to Twitter, has yet to live up to its full potential. Despite having 130 million monthly active users, it missed the chance to shine during the recent earthquake that hit the New York/New Jersey area. The conversations about the earthquake on Threads were scattered, with users tagging their discussions as EarthquakeThreads, NYC Threads, or simply Earthquake, making it difficult for any single term to gain momentum and break into the top trends.
meta_desc:
Meta's Instagram Threads: Improve Real-Time Event Handling

Instagram Threads, Meta's competitor to Twitter, has 130 million monthly active users but missed the mark during the recent earthquake in the New York/New Jersey area. The app lacked a clear, centralized location for users to share earthquake experiences and updates, resulting in scattered conversations and difficulty finding relevant information. Meta can improve Threads' real-time event handling with a dedicated trending page or more prominent hashtag display. Meta InstagramThreads EarthquakeUpdates

post_title: X makes Grok chatbot available to premium subscribers
title:
Title: xAI's Grok Chatbot Now for Social Network X's Premium Users: A Game-Changer?

Social network X expands access to xAI's Grok chatbot for Premium & Premium+ users, aiming to rival OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic. SEOtitle GrokChatbot SocialNetworkX
post_content:
Title: Exclusive Access to xAI's Grok Chatbot: A Game-Changer for Social Network X's Premium Users

Social network X has recently announced that it will be granting Premium tier subscribers access to xAI's Grok chatbot. This announcement comes after Elon Musk announced the expansion of the chatbot to more paid users last month. The company confirmed that only Premium and Premium+ users can interact with the chatbot in select regions.

Previously, Grok was only available to Premium+ users, who paid a $16 per month or a $168 per year subscription fee. However, with the latest update, users paying $8 per month can now access the chatbot. Users can engage with Grok in either "Regular mode" or "Fun mode," with labels indicating when the chatbot might return inaccurate answers.

Grok's capabilities go beyond simple summarization. Recently, Social network X introduced a new explore view inside Grok, which summarizes trending news stories. However, Grok takes it a step further by generating headlines, although there have been instances where the chatbot produced inaccurate information. For example, Grok wrote a fake headline stating "Iran Strikes Tel Aviv with Heavy Missiles."

Elon Musk's intention behind expanding access to Grok is likely to rival other products such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT, Google’s Gemini, or Anthropic’s Claude. Musk has been openly critical of OpenAI's operations over the last few months, even going so far as to sue the company in March over what he perceives as a betrayal of its non-profit goal. In response, OpenAI filed papers seeking the dismissal of all of Musk’s claims and released email exchanges between the Tesla CEO and the company.

In addition to opening up access to Grok, xAI also open-sourced the chatbot but without providing any training data details. While this raises questions about whether this is the latest version of the model and if the company will be more transparent about its approach to the development of the model and information about the training data, it's clear that Grok is a powerful tool that Social network X's Premium users can now take advantage of.

In conclusion, Social network X's decision to grant
meta_desc:

post_title: A framework to improve air-ground robot navigation in complex occlusion-prone environments
title: AGRNav: Enhancing Air-Ground Robot Navigation in Occlusion-Prone Environments
post_content:
Title: AGRNav: Revolutionizing Air-Ground Robot Navigation in Occlusion-Prone Environments

Introduction

Robotic systems have become increasingly prevalent in various indoor environments, assisting humans in performing manual tasks and answering simple queries. However, the future holds the potential for these robots to navigate unknown and unmapped outdoor environments, where obstacles may easily obstruct their sensors, increasing the risk of collisions. Air-ground robots, in particular, could be highly effective for navigating complex outdoor settings and tackling intricate tasks. Recently, researchers from the University of Hong Kong introduced AGRNav, a novel framework designed to enhance the autonomous navigation of air-ground robots in occlusion-prone environments.

The Challenge: Occlusions in Complex Environments

Air-ground robots possess exceptional mobility and long endurance, making them suitable for a wide range of applications, from searching for survivors after natural disasters to delivering packages to remote locations. However, navigating complex environments, such as forests and large buildings, poses a significant challenge due to the presence of occluded and unknown regions. Existing mapping-based and learning-based navigation methods often result in suboptimal trajectories for these robots.

The AGRNav Framework: A Solution

To address this challenge, the researchers developed AGRNav, a framework consisting of two main components: a lightweight semantic scene completion network (SCONet) and a hierarchical path planner. The SCONet component predicts the distribution of obstacles in an environment and their semantic features using a deep learning approach that requires minimal computational power. The hierarchical path planner, on the other hand, uses the predictions made by SCONet to plan optimal, energy-efficient aerial and ground paths for the robot to reach a specified location.

The SCONet component captures contextual information and occlusion area features by employing a self-attention mechanism, enabling accurate obstacle predictions. Following this, a query-based method is used for low-latency updates of prediction results to the grid map. Finally, the hierarchical path planner searches for energy-saving paths based on the updated map.

AGRNav in Action: Superior Performance in Simulations and Real-World Experiments

The researchers evaluated AGRNav using both simulations and real-world experiments, applying
meta_desc:
Meta Description: Revolutionize air-ground robot navigation in complex environments with AGRNav! This novel framework, combining SCONet and a hierarchical planner, predicts obstacles and plans energy-efficient paths, outperforming existing techniques in simulations and real-world tests.

Keyphrase: Autonomous Navigation, AGRNav, air-ground robots, complex environments, SCONet, hierarchical path planner

Title: AGRNav: Revolutionizing Air-Ground Robot Navigation in Occlusion-Prone Environments

Introduction:
Robotic systems, including air-ground robots, are increasingly prevalent in various environments, but navigating complex, occlusion-prone outdoor settings poses challenges. To tackle this, researchers from the University of Hong Kong introduced AGRNav, a novel framework designed for enhancing air-ground robot navigation in such environments.

The Challenge:
Navigating complex environments, such as forests and large buildings, with air-ground robots is difficult due to the presence of occluded and unknown regions. Existing mapping-based and learning-based navigation methods often result in suboptimal trajectories for these robots.

The AGRNav Framework:
AGRNav comprises two main components: a lightweight semantic scene completion network (SCONet) and a hierarchical path planner. SCONet predicts the distribution of obstacles and their semantic features using minimal computational power. The hierarchical path planner searches for optimal, energy-efficient aerial and ground paths based on SCONet's predictions.

AGRNav in Action:
The researchers evaluated AGRNav using simulations and real-world experiments, comparing it to existing mapping-based and learning-based techniques. In simulations, AGRNav achieved a 95% success rate, and in real-world experiments, it achieved a 90% success rate, outperforming other methods in terms of both success rate and energy efficiency.

Conclusion:
AGRNav is an attractive solution for autonomous navigation of air-ground robots in complex, occlusion-prone environments. Its ability to accurately predict obstacle distributions and semantic features while consuming minimal computational power makes it an attractive choice for various applications. post_title: Elon Musk says he'll unveil a Tesla robotaxi on August 8
title: Tesla's Robotaxi Unveiled on August 8: Musk's Autonomous Vision
post_content:
Title: The Future of Mobility: Tesla's Robotaxi Revelation

Elon Musk, the enigmatic CEO of Tesla, recently made headlines by announcing the unveiling of a robotaxi on August 8. This announcement comes in the wake of Tesla's EV sales lagging and profits falling, leaving the company and its CEO in search of a new product to boost sales or the stock price.

Previously, Reuters reported that Tesla was abandoning its plan to build a lower-cost EV. Instead, the company would focus its resources on a robotaxi, which is being developed on the same small EV platform initially intended for the affordable car. Musk quickly dismissed these claims on X, the social network he owns, labeling Reuters as "lying" without providing any specific disputes.

Throughout the years, rumors have circulated about Tesla working on two vehicles: a traditional car and one without a steering wheel or pedals. Musk has wavered between prioritizing a typical car or a more unconventional vehicle, even as his engineers insisted on referencing a car with standard controls. According to Walter Isaacson's biography of Musk, the CEO resisted this push, but lead designer Franz von Holzhausen and engineering VP Lars Moravy maintained a more traditional car version as a "shadow project."

Musk has long promised autonomous capabilities in Tesla vehicles. In 2016, he claimed that a Tesla would drive itself cross-country by the end of 2017, a goal that was never met. In 2019, he promised to launch the company's first robotaxis and establish an autonomous ride-sharing network in 2020, another pledge that went unfulfilled. Despite these setbacks, Musk still asserts that a dedicated robotaxi with no steering wheel or pedals will come to market by 2024.

Tesla vehicles are equipped with a driver-assistance system called Autopilot, and for an additional $12,000, owners can purchase "full self-driving" (FSD). FSD is a feature that Musk has promised will one day deliver full autonomous driving capabilities. However, Tesla vehicles are not currently self-driving. The

post_title: Price of zero-day exploits rises as companies harden products against hackers
title: Skyrocketing Zero-Day Exploit Prices: A Sign of Increased Cybersecurity
post_content:
Title: The Soaring Value of Zero-Day Exploits: A New Era of Cybersecurity

Introduction

In the rapidly evolving world of cybersecurity, the demand for zero-day exploits has reached unprecedented levels. Zero-day exploits are tools that take advantage of unpatched vulnerabilities in software, which are unknown to the makers of that software. As products become more secure, the price and effort required to uncover these lucrative zero-days have increased. This article delves into the rising costs and challenges associated with acquiring and using zero-day exploits, focusing on the latest price list published by Crowdfense, a startup specializing in the sale of these tools to government agencies and contractors.

The Rising Cost of Zero-Day Exploits

Crowdfense's latest price list reveals a significant increase in the value of zero-day exploits compared to their previous list published in 2019. The highest payouts offered now are $7 million for iOS zero-days, $5 million for Android zero-days, $3.5 million for Safari zero-days, and $5 million for WhatsApp and iMessage zero-days. This surge in pricing can be attributed to the heightened security measures implemented by tech giants like Apple, Google, and Microsoft, making it increasingly difficult to exploit their devices and applications.

The Difficulty in Uncovering Zero-Days

As companies enhance their security features, the process of discovering and exploiting zero-day vulnerabilities becomes more challenging. Dustin Childs, head of threat awareness at Trend Micro ZDI, notes that it should be progressively harder to exploit software and devices year over year. Shane Huntley, the head of Google's Threat Analysis Group, concurs, stating that as more zero-day vulnerabilities are discovered and platform protections continue to improve, the time and effort required from attackers increase, resulting in a higher cost for their findings.

Google's 2023 report indicated that hackers used 97 zero-day vulnerabilities in the wild last year, with 75% of zero-days targeting Google products and Android being attributed to spyware vendors, which often work with zero-day brokers. Security analyst David Manouchehri, who has knowledge of the zero-day market, confirms
meta_desc:
Meta Description: Discover the surging costs of zero-day exploits and the challenges in uncovering them. Crowdfense's latest price list highlights $7M for iOS, $5M for Android, and more. Read now!

post_title: Snapchat turns off controversial 'Solar System' feature by default after bad press
title: Snapchat Tones Down "Solar System" Feature for Subscribers
post_content:
Title: Snapchat Adjusts "Solar System" Feature to Address User Concerns

In response to recent concerns about a Snapchat feature known as "Solar System," the company has decided to make adjustments to how it functions. This feature, which ranks paid subscribers based on their communication frequency with friends, has been accused of increasing anxiety among teenage users.

The Solar System feature organizes friends into a user's personal "solar system," with friends who are contacted more frequently positioned closer, similar to planets orbiting the sun. This system can lead to hurt feelings when users realize they aren't as close to their friends as they thought. Acknowledging user feedback, Snapchat has addressed the issue without eliminating the feature entirely.

Snapchat announced that the Solar System feature will now be turned off by default for Snapchat+ subscribers. Users can still enable the feature if they choose, allowing them to know when they are close to someone in their network. The company hopes this change will strike a balance between providing a desired feature and avoiding upsetting those who do not wish to use it.

However, it is unclear whether turning off the feature by default will have the desired effect. Teens, who make up a significant portion of Snapchat's user base, may actively seek out the feature and re-enable it. Snapchat has noted that only a small percentage (less than 0.25%) of the community uses the Solar System option. Still, it is important to consider how many Snapchat+ users have engaged with the feature.

The Solar System feature is one of several friend ranking systems offered by Snapchat. Another feature, "Best Friends," displays a user's most contacted friends at the top of their contact list, along with a heart or smiley emoji. Snapchat also offers "Streaks," a tool that encourages repeated app use by displaying the number of consecutive days users have stayed in touch with one another.

Although Snapchat has promised to mitigate the potential downsides of online communication, it has intentionally created features that have left the company open to lawsuits and Congressional inquiry. Snapchat's defense of the Solar System feature is that users wanted more awareness and context about their friendships. However, critics argue that these features are designed to keep young people engaged with the app
meta_desc: Meta Description: Snapchat adjusts "Solar System" feature to address user concerns - discover how Snapchat ranks friends and its impact on mental health. Learn more now. (101 characters)

post_title: EarliTec Diagnostics raises $21.5M to help diagnose autism earlier
title: EarliTec Diagnostics' $21.5M Funding for Early Autism Diagnosis
post_content:
Title: A New Era of Autism Diagnosis: EarliTec Diagnostics and the Advancements in Early Detection

Introduction

Autism, a complex neurodevelopmental condition, affects 1 in 36 children in the United States, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial for improving the developmental outcomes of children with autism. EarliTec Diagnostics, an Atlanta-based startup, is revolutionizing the autism diagnosis landscape with its innovative, AI-driven system that helps clinicians diagnose children as young as 16 months old. This blog post will delve into the story behind EarliTec Diagnostics, its cutting-edge technology, and the growing interest in autism-focused healthcare startups from venture capitalists (VCs).

EarliTec Diagnostics: A Groundbreaking Approach to Autism Diagnosis

EarliTec Diagnostics' FDA-authorized system employs artificial intelligence to analyze a child's eye movements while they watch short videos and engage in social interactions on a screen for 12 minutes. The device tracks the child's eye movements, revealing distinct patterns between children with and without autism. By offering a faster, more efficient diagnosis method, EarliTec's technology enables clinicians to work with more children and provide earlier intervention, which significantly impacts a child's developmental trajectory.

Raising Capital for Expansion and Research

EarliTec Diagnostics recently secured a $21.5 million Series B funding round co-led by Nexus NeuroTech Ventures and Venture Investors. This investment will aid the company in expanding its commercialization efforts, enhancing its assessment and treatment options, and conducting research to potentially diagnose a wider age range of children. Currently, EarliTec's system is used by eight clinicians across six states, with plans to grow its user base and impact.

The Growing Momentum in Autism-Focused Healthcare Startups

The increased interest in autism-focused healthcare startups is evident through recent funding initiatives. For example, the Autism Impact Fund raised a $60 million fund, 20% higher than its initial target of $50 million. Additionally, Divergent Ventures launched a $1
meta_desc:
Million fund for autism innovations. These developments highlight a growing commitment to autism diagnostics, intervention, and care.

Meta Description:

Discover the new era of autism diagnostics with EarliTec Diagnostics' AI-driven system, offering early detection for improved outcomes. Autism-focused healthcare startups secure millions in funding, driving innovation and advancements. Act now for a brighter future for autism care. post_title: IVP's Eric Liaw talks Klarna controversy, sticky successions, and why the great valuation reset doesn't really matter
title: IVP's Eric Liaw Talks Fundraising, Europe, and Klarna Drama
post_content:
Title: A Candid Conversation with Eric Liaw of IVP: Fundraising, Succession, and Portfolio Insights

Introduction

In the ever-evolving world of venture capital, IVP's recent closing of its 18th fund with $1.6 billion in capital commitments is a notable achievement. I had the opportunity to speak with Eric Liaw, a longtime general partner at IVP, to discuss the fundraising process, succession, and portfolio companies, including the recent drama surrounding Klarna.

Fundraising in a Choppy Market

When asked about the fundraising process, Liaw described it as "choppy," pointing out that the environment in 2018, when they raised their sixteenth fund, was significantly different from the one in 2021. Despite the challenges, IVP remained consistent in their approach, choosing not to raise an excessive amount of capital and deploy it quickly. This strategy has allowed them to maintain their focus and avoid the pitfalls experienced by some of their industry peers.

Expanding to Europe and the Klarna Drama

Liaw, who recently relocated to London, mentioned that IVP's expansion to Europe was an organic extension of their existing strategy. They made their first investment in Europe back in 2006 and have since built a portfolio of 20 companies across 10 different countries.
meta_desc:
Meta Description:
Explore fundraising insights with Eric Liaw of IVP, managing $1.6B in capital commitments. Learn about their consistent approach, expansion to Europe, and handling succession. VentureCapital Fundraising

post_title: Canoo reveals it paid for CEO's jet, AT&T leaks records and X announces NSFW plans
title: Apple Home Robot, AT&T Data Leak, Canoo CEO Jet Expense
post_content:
Welcome to this week’s tech roundup, where we distill the most interesting developments in the world of technology into a concise and engaging format for your reading pleasure.

Y Combinator’s Demo Days: Skepticism and Innovation

Y Combinator, the famed startup accelerator, recently held its Demo Days, and our venture desk team took a critical look at the event. Our coverage includes a recap of day one and day two, along with an AI roundup and insightful analysis from our dedicated editorial team. Amidst the excitement, Microsoft and quantum computing startup Quantinuum announced a scientific breakthrough, claiming to have run thousands of quantum computer experiments without a single error.

Apple's Home Robot Adventure

Following the cancellation of its autonomous EV project, Apple has reportedly shifted its focus to home robots. The tech giant has assigned its Apple Home and AI executives to work on some form of robotics project for households. Although details are still being finalized, this development has certainly piqued the interest of tech enthusiasts and industry experts alike.

This Week's Headlines
- Canoo, the EV startup, paid $1.7 million in 2023 for its CEO's private jet rental, which is double the amount of revenue the company generated that year.
- Phone giant AT&T has reset millions of account passcodes following a data leak earlier this month, which exposed a huge cache of customer records online.
- OpenAI has made its flagship conversational AI, ChatGPT, accessible to everyone, even those without an account, although the experience may differ.
- Microsoft has introduced new versions of its Microsoft 365 and Office 365 subscription services, excluding Teams following scrutiny from EU regulators and complaints from rival Slack.

Startups and Shutdowns

Ghost Autonomy, a startup working on autonomous driving software for automaker partners, has shut down after raising nearly $220 million. The company's closure highlights the challenges many startups face in the competitive autonomous driving market.

Alphabet and HubSpot: An Unlikely Pair?

Reuters reported that Alphabet, Google's parent company, is exploring the possibility of acquiring HubSpot, a CRM and marketing automation company with a market cap of over $3
meta_desc:
$3 billion. While Google has a strong suite of business software, acquiring HubSpot could enhance its marketing and sales capabilities, creating a powerful duo in the enterprise software market. Stay tuned for updates on this potential merger.

Privacy: The Top Priority

In the wake of recent data breaches and leaks, protecting user data has never been more critical. Discover the importance of end-to-end encryption, data minimization, and user control. We also delve into the potential of privacy-focused search engines like DuckDuckGo and Brave Search, offering alternatives to data-hungry giants like Google.

Join the Conversation

Stay informed on the latest tech news and trends, including mergers, innovations, and more. Follow our comprehensive tech coverage, with daily articles, social media updates, and podcast episodes. Engage with our community of tech enthusiasts and stay ahead in the fast-paced world of technology.

Stay informed, engaged, and ahead of the curve in the world of technology. Follow our tech roundups and join our growing community of tech enthusiasts.

post_title: New U.S. ‘green bank’ aims to steer over $160B in capital into climate tech
title:
Green Bank's $20B to Draw $160B+ in Climate Tech Investments

The Environmental Protection Agency has allocated $20 billion in grants from the Inflation Reduction Act to eight organizations. This Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund aims to attract $7 in private capital for every dollar dispersed, targeting underfinanced climate tech projects and benefiting low-income communities.
post_content:
Title: The New Green Bank: A Game-Changer for Climate Tech Investments

A significant development in the realm of climate technology financing has emerged in the United States. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has recently allocated $20 billion in grants from the Inflation Reduction Act to eight organizations. These organizations will utilize the funds to provide loans, targeting underfinanced yet crucial projects, such as residential heat pump installations and affordable housing retrofits.

The newly established Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund aims to address the long-standing challenge of smaller-scale projects being overlooked by financial institutions due to lower profitability. Traditional banks have historically favored large-scale renewable energy projects, like utility-scale solar and wind farms. However, the demand for climate tech solutions at the residential and small business level remains high.

Dawn Lippert, CEO and founder of Elemental Excelerator, expressed her excitement to TechCrunch, stating, "It's a chance to prove that this works and creates real benefit on the ground for people across America...tribal communities, rural communities, low-income and disadvantaged communities are really the focus here." Indeed, over $14 billion of the funding will be directed towards these specific communities.

With the potential to attract $7 in private capital for every dollar dispersed, the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund could have a far-reaching impact. This multiplier effect might even surpass expectations, as McKinsey estimates the new green bank could draw more than $12 in private investment per dollar on its balance sheet.

Although the $20 billion fund may appear modest compared to the $27 trillion required for the U.S. to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 (as per McKinsey's estimates), its capacity to stimulate private investment and serve as a recurring funding source offers the potential for extensive influence beyond its initial financial scope.

Startups and investors can also reap benefits from this new initiative. While the primary focus is on consumers and small businesses, equity investments are a possibility. The funding is expected to boost demand for ready-to-deploy climate technologies, while simultaneously sending a clear message to innovators and investors that there is a market for consumer-level climate tech tailored for low-income and disadvantaged communities.

Lippert highlights the potential of

Meta Description:

Unlock the potential of climate tech investments with the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund. Drive $160 billion in private capital and foster growth in underrepresented communities. Apply now! GreenBank ClimateTech Investments

post_title: Tesla will unveil a robotaxi on August 8, according to Musk
title: Tesla's Robotaxi Unveiling Amid Affordable EV Uncertainty
post_content:
Title: Tesla's Robotaxi Set to Launch Amidst Affordable EV Speculations

Introduction

In a surprising turn of events, Tesla is gearing up to unveil its much-anticipated robotaxi on August 8, as announced by CEO Elon Musk, following reports that the automaker has shelved its plans to develop a low-cost electric vehicle (EV). This announcement comes after Reuters published an article stating that Tesla was abandoning its affordable EV project, which was expected to be priced around $25,000. Musk quickly dismissed the report, stating that Reuters was "lying (again)," but he did not specify which part of the article he was contesting.

The Core Announcement: Tesla's Robotaxi

Amidst the controversy, one thing is certain: Tesla is moving ahead with its robotaxi plans. Musk's tweet confirmed the August 8 unveiling, but he did not provide any further details about the upcoming robotaxi. The challenge lies in creating a robotaxi that can function effectively with Tesla's camera-only system, as the company removed radar and other sensors from its driver assistance technologies a few years ago. This is a bold move, considering that other robotaxi companies, such as Waymo, rely heavily on radar and lidar technologies for their autonomous vehicles.

Affordable EV: A Continuous Pursuit

Tesla has long been promising an affordable EV, with expectations that the vehicle would hit the market with a starting price of around $25,000. Musk himself expressed optimism about this model's arrival in the second half of 2025 during a Q4 2022 earnings call. However, the Reuters report suggests that the company has changed course, focusing its efforts solely on robotaxis.

In response to the report, Musk accused Reuters of lying, but he did not explicitly deny that the affordable EV project had been canceled. With Tesla's cheapest vehicle being the Model 3, which starts at $39,000, the market is still waiting for a more budget-friendly electric vehicle from the automaker.

Conclusion

Tesla's robotaxi launch on August 8 will undoubtedly be
meta_desc:
a groundbreaking event in the world of autonomous vehicles. As the company continues to push the boundaries of what's possible in the realm of self-driving technology, questions surrounding the affordable EV remain unanswered. However, one thing is for sure: Tesla's commitment to revolutionizing transportation is stronger than ever. Stay tuned for more updates as the August 8 unveiling approaches.

Meta Description:

Unveiling of Tesla's Robotaxi on August 8; Will the affordable EV become a reality? Stay updated on the groundbreaking event in autonomous vehicles. Tesla Robotaxi AutonomousVehicles EV
